{{Infobox book| | name = Givi Shaduri | image = | title_orig = გივი შადური | translator = | author = [[Mikheil Javakhishvili]] | cover_artist = | country = [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | language = [[Georgian Language|Georgian]] | series = | genre = [[Epistolary novel]]
[[Adventure fiction]] | publisher = | release_date = [[1928 in literature| 1928]] | media_type = Print (hardback) | pages = 200 pages | isbn = }} '''''Givi Shaduri''''' ({{lang-ka|გივი შადური}}; ''Givi Shaduri'') is a fourth novel by [[Georgians|Georgian]] novelist [[Mikheil Javakhishvili]]. It was first published in [[1928 in literature| 1928]]. During his life, it was published several times. It is reputed to one of the best adventure novel in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].მიხეილ ჯავახიშვილი, რჩეული თხზულებანი ექვს ტომად. ტომი II. გვ. 583. სახელმწიფო გამომცემლობა "საბჭოთა საქართველო" თბილისი, 1959 წელი [[Mikheil Javakhishvili]] wrote the novel ''Givi Shaduri'' in 1928. The novel follows the adventure genre. It is made up of five independent stories, which have one common character - the story teller, the title named Givi Shaduri. ==Plot== The narrator of the novel - Givi Shaduri is talking to the reader from the Feast. Shaduri is the elderly and people skilled in life. Each story of his hard life have used many adventures episode. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Europe-novel-stub}} {{Mikheil Javakhishvili}} [[Category:Literature of Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Georgian novels]] [[Category:1928 novels]] [[Category:Novels by Mikheil Javakhishvili]] [[Category:Adventure novels]] [[Category:Epistolary novels]]

{{unreferenced|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox company |name = Globecast |logo = Globecast building entrance.jpg |type = |genre = |foundation = |founder = |location_city = [[Issy les Moulineaux]] |location_country = [[France]] |origins = |key_people = Christian Pinon, Olivier Barberot, Philippe Bernard |area_served = |industry = [[Telecommunication]]s, [[Broadcasting]] |products = Media processing and transmission services for television broadcasters and content owners |services = |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |num_employees = |parent = [[Orange S.A.]] |divisions = |subsid = |owner = |caption = |homepage = [http://www.globecast.com/ www.globecast.com] |dissolved = |footnotes = }}
'''Globecast''' is a service company for the radio, television and [[media (communication)|media]] industry, providing solutions for media and [[content management]], aggregation, formatting, processing, transmission and distribution. These contents are feeding various television and radio platforms: [[direct-broadcast satellite]] (DBS), [[digital terrestrial television]] (DTT), [[cable TV]], [[IPTV]], TV for internet connected screens ([[Internet television|OTT TV]]), [[digital signage]] networks, cinema theaters ([[Digital Cinema Package|DCP]] and live events delivery). Globecast is a key player in this industry, serving the needs for top 100 television broadcasters in the world.
Globecast has an established presence in Europe, America, Asia, Africa, Middle-East and Australia, through nineteen points of presence, among them twelve satellite telecommunication [[Earth station#Telecommunications port|teleports]] and technical operation centers, all of them linked via an international terrestrial telecommunication network.
The company is fully owned by [[Orange S.A.|Orange]]. It is currently led by Philippe Bernard (previous CEO was Olivier Barberot; and before him Christian Pinon, Alain Baget).
In 2013, Globecast changed its visual identity ([[logo]]) and its name lost the uppercase C (former writing was '''GlobeCast''').
== History == * Autumn 1996: in France, activities of [[France Telecom]] in the broadcast industry are split between two new entities: Division Multimedia (DMM) and Division des Entreprises Audiovisuelles (DEA).
The DEA is composed by the [[TDF Group|TDF]] (TéléDiffusion de France) company and Direction des Transmissions Audiovisuelles (DTA). DTA will then become known as GlobeCast.
The DEA also covers: # the "Audiovisuel International" (AVI) marketing department of France Telecom Réseaux & Services Internationaux (FTRSI); # the shares of the following companies: 100% of Maxat (UK), 40% of Keystone (USA) and 20% of TIBA (Argentina); # the services of Direction des Opérations of TDF; # three operation centers of FTRSI, TDF and the Direction des réseaux Nationaux (DRN); # the "delegation of the image service", which purpose was the promotion of the '''Telecom 2''' satellite.
* March 1997: The DTA is organized around an international coordination entity (DTA Worldwide) and three business units: DTA France, Maxat and Keystone, now fully controlled by DEA. DTA also buys IDB's assets, managed by Keystone since 1995. * April 1997: The "corporate television" activities of France Câbles & Radio (subsidiary of France Telecom) are now part of DTA. * April 1997: The whole business activities are now operated under the brand name of GlobeCast. * September 1997: GlobeCast Asia is established in Singapore and becomes a new sales office of Globecast for the Asian market. * January 1998: GlobeCast Italia is the new office of GlobeCast for serving the Italian and Swiss market, thanks to the partnership with Dominique Curchod Communication. * February 1998: Hero Productions in Miami (USA) is purchased by Globecast. Activities of this subsidiary are television production and transmission. After merging it with Keystone, the name is changed to GlobeCast North America. * June 1998: Majority of shares of Newsforce (South Africa) are purchased by Globecast. Newsforce is well established on the South African markets, with offices in Australia and Singapore. * January 1999: GlobeCast Spain is incorporated in partnership with the Spanish group [[Mediapro]]. * March 2000: GlobeCast Asia launches its full-time monitoring center and opens its booking call-center for handling the whole operations is Asia. During the September 11th 2001 events in NYC (USA), this entity is at the center stage for all related activities for all the GlobeCast group. * June 2002: The DTA division of France Telecom is incorporated as GlobeCast France SAS and GlobeCast Holding, giving birth to the GlobeCast group. * February 2003: GlobeCast India is incorporated. * February 2003: Mediasat (Australia), specialised in satellite television transmition, is merged with the Australian offices of GlobeCast (formerly Newsforce), giving birth to GlobeCast Australia. GlobeCast has 50% of shares. * January 2006: GlobeCast Spain is merged with Mediasat (subsidiary of [[Mediapro]]), including activities of [[Abertis]] Telecom in the broadcast industry, giving birth to Overon. GlobeCast has 12% of Overon, who becomes its Spanish partner. In January 2008, GlobeCast sells all its share to Mediapro. * June 2008: GlobeCast Asia enhances its presence by purchasing Pacific Century Matrix (Hong Kong). It is the fifth office and technical operation center in Asia (after Singapore, New Delhi, Beijin, Seoul). * August 2008 : [[NETIA (software)|Nétia]], a software editor for radio automation and media management, is purchased by GlobeCast, accelerating its transition toward the media management industry. * April 2010 : GlobeCast Cinema Delivery is launched for the cinema theaters in France. It is a service to deliver [[digital cinema]] film copies to theaters via telecommunication networks. * October 2010: GlobeCast purchases from [[Technicolor SA]] a television 'play-out' and post-production center, located in Singapore. * September 2012: GlobeCast relaunches its OTT TV ([[Over-the-top content|Over-the-top television]]) allowing broadcasters and TV bouquet operators to target multiscreen internet television users all around the world. * September 2013: '''Globecast''' changes its visual identity, with a new logo and a name writing without the capital C. * June 2015: Globecast Australia became a wholly owned subsidiary of Telstra Australia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globecast.com.au/http%3A//www.globecast.com.au/news/press-release/Telstra-Purchase-of-Globecast-Australia-Concludes|title=Telstra Purchase of Globecast Australia Concludes|publisher=}}</ref> and in September 2015 was rebranded as Telstra Broadcast Services. * January 2017: [[NETIA (software)|Nétia]] subsidiary is sold.
== SERTE == The technical operation center of Globecast in Paris (France), located at 61 rue des Archives, was long time known as '''SERTE'''. This name is still used sometimes by television professionals, even outside France, because it was used for many years. This technical center is a major routing node for television and radio feeds.
The SERTE acronym used to refer to: Service d'Exploitation Radio Télévision Extérieur (in English, Foreign radio and television operation center).
A brief history of SERTE: * 1947: creation of Centre des Liaisons Radio-Électriques - CLR * 1962: first satellite transmission operated at CLR * 1980: CLR becomes SERTE, the national center, then international, for television and radio transmitions * 1989: incorporation to the France Télécom group * since 1980: it is one of the prime international hub for television and radio transmitions, either via satellite and terrestrial telecom networks * 2002: GlobeCast is incorporated, including the technique operation center in Paris, rue des Archives (ex-SERTE)
== Digital cinema == In France, Globecast operates a service to deliver digital film copies ([[Digital Cinema Package|DCP]]) to theaters via terrestrial telecom networks.
== World TV and MyGlobeTV ==
In the USA, Globecast operated a television bouquet via satellite under the name '''[[GlobeCast World TV|World TV]]''' and an internet television bouquet under the name '''MyGlobeTV'''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
=== External links === * {{Official|http://www.globecast.com }}

Winstona Churchilla 2, [[Prague]] | website = [http://www.zeleni.cz/ www.zeleni.cz] | seats1_title = [[Chamber of Deputies of the Czech Republic|Chamber of Deputies]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|200|hex={{Green Party (Czech Republic)/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[Senate of the Czech Republic|Senate]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|4|81|hex={{Green Party (Czech Republic)/meta/color}}}} | seats3_title = [[European Parliament]] | seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|22|hex={{Green Party (Czech Republic)/meta/color}}}} | seats4_title = Regional Assemblies | seats4 = {{Composition bar|9|675|hex={{Green Party (Czech Republic)/meta/color}}}} | seats5_title = Local Assemblies | seats5 = {{Composition bar|323|62178|hex={{Green Party (Czech Republic)/meta/color}}}} }} The '''Green Party''' ({{lang-cs|Strana zelených}}) is a political party in the [[Czech Republic]]. The party held a single seat ([[Jaromír Štětina]]) in the [[Senate of the Czech Republic|Senate]] (upper house of the [[Parliament of the Czech Republic]]) between 2004 and 2010. In the [[Czech legislative election, 2006|2006 legislative election]] the party received 6.3% of the vote and won six seats in the lower house – the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Czech Republic|Chamber of Deputies]]. This subsequently led to taking part in the governing coalition, together with the [[Civic Democratic Party (Czech Republic)|Civic Democrats]] (ODS) and the [[Christian Democratic Union - Czechoslovak People's Party|Christian Democrats]] (KDU–ČSL) from January 2007 to March 2009 (for more details see [[Mirek Topolánek's Second Cabinet]]). However the Green Party was unable to repeat its success in [[Czech legislative election, 2010|2010 elections]], losing all seats in both chambers. == Election results == === Chamber of deputies of the Czech Republic === {{Green politics sidebar}} {| class="wikitable" ! {{Infobox scientist | name = Helen Amanda Fricker | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age |1969|05|03}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = British | fields = [[Glaciology]]

PhD [[University of Tasmania]] | thesis_title = Applications of ERS Satellite Altimetry in Lambert-Amery System, Antarctica | thesis_url = | thesis_year = 1999 | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = | awards = Muse Prize (2010) | signature = | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|http://scrippsscholars.ucsd.edu/hafricker}} | footnotes = | spouse = | children = | death_cause = | education = | partner = }} '''Helen Amanda Fricker''' (born 1969) is a [[glaciologist]] and professor at [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]] at the [[University of California]], San Diego and won the 2010 Martha T. Muse Prize for Science and Policy in Antarctica. == Early life and education == Helen attended [[Altrincham Grammar School for Girls]], where she encountered Melissa Lord, a young and energetic female physics teacher who steered her onto the path of becoming a scientist.{{Cite web|url=http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/science/contenthandler.cfm?id=2247|title=The Antarctic Sun: News about Antarctica – Taking the Prize|website=antarcticsun.usap.gov|access-date=2016-05-30}} In 1991, she received her B.Sc. in Mathematics and Physics from [[University College London]] (UCL), with first-class honours.{{Cite web|url=http://scrippsscholars.ucsd.edu/hafricker/biocv|title=Bio|website=Research Profiles|access-date=2016-05-30}} In her final year at UCL, she took an Earth science course from a lecturer, [[Chris Rapley]], who was leader of the Remote Sensing Group at UCL and would later become the director of the [[British Antarctic Survey]]. Chris Rapley, encouraged her to do a dissertation on using remote-sensing data to track icebergs in the Antarctic during her final year. This course turned her attention toward Antarctica — and got her started on a career in glaciology.{{Cite journal|last=Gewin|first=Virginia|date=2010-09-15|title=Helen Amanda Fricker|url=http://www.nature.com/naturejobs/science/articles/10.1038/nj7313-359a|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=467|issue=7313|pages=359–359|doi=10.1038/nj7313-359a}} She earned her Ph.D. in glaciology from the Institute of Antarctic and Southern Ocean Studies, [[University of Tasmania]], Australia in 1998. In 1999, Fricker began her work at the [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]] as a postgraduate researcher. Fricker is now a Professor of Geophysics in the Cecil H. and Ida M. Green Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics at Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UC San Diego.{{Cite web|url=http://scrippsscholars.ucsd.edu/hafricker|title=Research Profiles|website=Research Profiles|access-date=2016-05-30}} She and her husband Glyn Fricker have three daughters. == Career and impact == Fricker has authored over 80 publications relating to the [[Remote sensing (archaeology)|satellite remote sensing]] of Antarctica's [[Ice shelf|ice shelves]] and active [[Subglacial lake|subglacial lakes]].{{Cite web|url=http://glaciology.weebly.com/publications.html|title=Publications|website=glaciology.weebly.com|access-date=2016-05-30}} Fricker is widely recognized for her discovery of active subglacial lakes,{{Cite journal|last=Fricker|first=Helen Amanda|last2=Scambos|first2=Ted|last3=Bindschadler|first3=Robert|last4=Padman|first4=Laurie|date=2007-03-16|title=An Active Subglacial Water System in West Antarctica Mapped from Space|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/315/5818/1544|journal=Science|language=en|volume=315|issue=5818|pages=1544–1548|doi=10.1126/science.1136897|pmid=17303716|bibcode=2007Sci...315.1544F}} and she has shown that these lakes form dynamic hydrologic systems, where one lake can drain into another in a short period of time. Fricker was the first to describe [[Lake Whillans]] in 2007, an active subglacial lake in West Antarctica, which was subsequently the first such environment to be sampled and found to contain life.{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/02/130205-antarctica-ice-life-moons-science-environment-lakes/|title=Life Found Deep Under Antarctic Ice for First Time?|date=5 February 2013|publisher=National Geographic Daily News|author=Kaufman, Marc|accessdate=2013-02-20}} She is also known for her innovative research into Antarctic ice shelf mass budget processes such as iceberg calving and basal melting and freezing. Her research focuses on ice sheets in Antarctica and Greenland and their role in the climate system and on subglacial hydrology. She uses a combination of satellite radar and laser altimetry and other remote-sensing data to understand ice sheet processes.{{Cite web|url=http://glaciology.weebly.com/projects.html|title=Projects|website=glaciology.weebly.com|access-date=2016-05-30}} Some specific processes Fricker investigates include subglacial hydrology by monitoring the activity of subglacial lakes under the ice streams, ice flexure from tidal activity in the grounding zone, basal melting and freezing under the ice shelves, and the propagation and evolution of active ice shelf rifts, which eventually lead to iceberg calving. Fricker was one of the primary investigators on the Whillans Ice Stream Subglacial Access Research Drilling (WISSARD) project,{{Cite web|url=http://www.wissard.org/about/wissard-personnel|title=Personnel {{!}} WISSARD|website=www.wissard.org|access-date=2016-05-30}} which became the first group to drill into an Antarctic subglacial lake, Subglacial Lake Whillans, in 2013{{Cite journal|last=Fox|first=Douglas|date=2014-08-21|title=Lakes under the ice: Antarctica’s secret garden|url=http://www.nature.com/news/lakes-under-the-ice-antarctica-s-secret-garden-1.15729|journal=Nature|volume=512|issue=7514|pages=244–246|doi=10.1038/512244a|pmid=25143097|bibcode=2014Natur.512..244F}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21231380|title=Drill reaches Antarctica's under-ice Lake Whillans|last=Amos|first=Jonathan|date=28 January 2013|publisher=[[BBC]]|access-date=22 June 2016}} Fricker has held numerous positions relating to her study of the [[cryosphere]], including Chair of AGU's Cryospheric Sciences Focus Group from 2004–2006, Elected Member of the ICESat Science Team from 2006–present, as part of the Ice, Cloud and land Elevation ([[ICESat]]) mission from 1999–present and the [[ICESat-2]] Science Definition Team and the NASA Sea Level Change Team. She runs the Scripps Glaciology group at Scripps Institution of Oceanography. == Awards and honors == Fricker received the Royal Tasmania Society Doctoral Award for her PhD in 2001.{{Cite web|url=http://rst.org.au/awards/past-recipients/|title=Past Recipients|website=rst.org.au|access-date=2016-05-30}} She received the [[NASA Group Achievement Award|NASA Group Achievement]] Award for her role in the Ice, Cloud, and Land Elevation Satellite ([[ICESat]]) Mission Development Team in 2004.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/vision/earth/lookingatearth/antarctic_plumb_bios_prt.htm|title=NASA – Biographies|website=www.nasa.gov|language=en|access-date=2016-05-30}} In 2010, she was awarded the Martha T. Muse Prize for Science and Policy in Antarctica by the Tinker Foundation and the [[Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research|Scientific Committee on Antarctic]] Research{{Cite web|url=http://www.museprize.org/news.html|title=Tinker-Muse Prize for Science and Policy in Antarctica|website=www.museprize.org|access-date=2016-05-30}}{{Cite web|url=https://scripps.ucsd.edu/news/2000|title=Scripps Glaciologist Awarded 2010 Muse Prize for Science and Policy in Antarctica {{!}} Scripps Institution of Oceanography, UC San Diego|website=scripps.ucsd.edu|access-date=2016-05-30}} ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==External links== * [https://scholar.google.co.uk/citations?user=5prTIdoAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao Helen Fricker] on [[Google Scholar]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fricker, Helen}} [[Category:Glaciologists]] [[Category:American women scientists]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:1969 births]]

{{Infobox company |name = NOVA Cyprus |logo = NOVA Cyprus.jpg |type = Private |genre = |foundation = July 1, 2004 |founder = |location_city = |location_country = Cyprus |location = |origins = |key_people = |area_served = Cyprus |industry = [[Telecommunications]] |products = [[Direct Broadcast Satellite]] |services = |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |num_employees = |parent = |divisions = |subsid = |owner = Multichoice Cyprus (July 1, 2004 - June 2011)
[[Forthnet]](July 2011- ) |slogan = |homepage = http://www.nova-cyprus.com |dissolved = |footnotes = }} '''NOVA Cyprus''' is a [[Cyprus|Cypriot]] [[digital television|digital]] satellite [[Pay TV|pay television]] service owned by [[Multichoice Cyprus]]. NOVA launched in July 2004 and was the first DTH satellite provider to launch in Cyprus. It is one of two satellite platforms, the other being [[Athina Sat]]. From November 2007, NOVA Cyprus was also available via PrimeTV IPTV service of [[PrimeTel]] but a few years later Nova Cyprus was removed from the IPTV service.{{cite web | url=http://www.dmeurope.com/default.asp?ArticleID=27853 | title=PrimeTel adds NOVA channels to IP TV platform | accessdate=2007-12-15}} NOVA offers Cypriot subscribers an array of programming choices from News, Sports, Movies, Children's & Entertainment. From 1 July 2011 both LTV and Alfa removed definitely from NOVA Cyprus because the two sides were not able to come to an agreement after the dissolution of Multichoice Cyprus. Then NOVA Cyprus is under the control of [[Forthnet]] and Multichoice Hellas and during the summer were added HD service (NovaCinema1,2 HD, NovaSports1,2 HD etc.) from [[NOVA Greece]] and some other channels. From 1 February 2012 all Nova channels (Novacinema 1-4 and Novasports 1-7) are available through the [[IPTV]] service of [[CytaVision]]. ==Dispute with LTV== "In July 2006, [[Lumiere TV|LTV]] pulled their service from the NOVA lineup, due to a dispute with Multichoice. In August 2006, [[Alfa TV]] was also removed from the NOVA line-up due to the same dispute." The channels then went on to sign with rival DTH provider [[Athina Sat]]. In 2008, the two sides resumed negotiations and were able to come to an agreement. As of March 3, 2008, both LTV and Alfa are now once again available through NOVA Cyprus [http://www.politis.com.cy/cgibin/hweb?-A=777153&-V=archive&-w=NOVA@CYPRUS@&-P Πολιτησ Online] ==External links== * [http://www.nova-cyprus.com Official Site] {{gr icon}} (English version is currently under construction) ==References== {{reflist}} {{CATV Europe}} [[Category:Media companies of Cyprus]] [[Category:Direct broadcast satellite services]]

{{Infobox company |name = NOVA Greece |foundation = December 1999 |location_city = Athens |location_country = Greece |key_people = Panos Papadopoulos ([[CEO]]) |area_served = Greece |industry = [[Telecommunications]] |products = [[Direct broadcast satellite]] |net_income = {{increase}}€150.0 million (2014)<ref>http://www.fortunegreece.com/article/ischiropii-ti-thesi-tis-forthnet/</ref> |num_employees = 340 (2014) |parent = [[Forthnet]] |divisions = |subsid = |owner = |caption = |homepage = {{URL|nova.gr}} |dissolved = |footnotes = }}
'''NOVA Greece''' is a Greek [[digital satellite]] [[pay TV]] platform owned by [[Multichoice Hellas]]. It was launched in December 1999.
NOVA offers Greek subscribers an array of international and domestic programmes (including news, sports, movies, music, children's programmes and general entertainment channels) plus the majority of popular Greek terrestrial TV channels along with a number of Greek terrestrial radio stations. International programmes are offered in their original soundtrack, with Greek subtitles. Some interactive services like games, cinema & theatre listings, lottery numbers, news headlines and weather reports are also provided.
On April 14, 2008, Greek telecommunications company [[Forthnet]] acquired Netmed, parent firm of NOVA Greece.<ref>[http://www.iii.co.uk/news/?type=afxnews&articleid=6656016&action=article Business finance news - currency market news - online UK currency markets - financial news - Interactive Investor]</ref>
In 2010, Nova Greece had 363,679 subscribers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2011/03/17/greek-satellite-subs-at-all-time-high/ |title=Greek satellite subs at all time high |publisher=Broadband TV News |date=2011-04-18 |accessdate=2011-03-17 }}</ref>
In March 2012, Nova Greece had 391,252 subscribers. HD service counted 52,968 subscribers in 2011, an 86,8% rise from 28,356 subscribers in 2010.
In the end June 2015 the platform had 509,088 subscribers, while one year later, June 2016 it had 460,252 (-9,6%).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitaltvinfo.gr/news/media-news/item/18027-thilia-sti-syndromitiki-tileorasi-i-kyvernitiki-forologisi|title=Θηλιά στη συνδρομητική τηλεόραση η κυβερνητική φορολόγηση|date=5 Σεπτεμβρίου 2016|website=digitaltvinfo}}</ref>
In August 2016 the OTE TV platform surpassed Nova Greece subscribers number, by reaching 462,000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.gr/money/epixeiriseis/story/45255/h-forologia-frenare-tin-agora-syndromitikis-tileorasis|title=Η φορολογία "φρέναρε" την αγορά συνδρομητικής τηλεόρασης|date=6 Σεπτεμβρίου 2016|website=Cnn Greece}}</ref>
In July 2017 it was referred that NOVA Greece had 430,000 subscribers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sport24.gr/Columns/panos-voglis/h-ert-sthrigma-ths-kentrikhs-diaxeirishs.4758743.html|title=Η ΕΡΤ στήριγμα της κεντρικής διαχείρισης|date=10 Ιουλίου 2017|website=Cnn Greece}}</ref>
== Technical information ==
Nova broadcasts in standard definition using the [[DVB-S]] [[MPEG-2]] format and (since September 2010) in [[High-definition video|high definition]] using the DVB-S [[MPEG-4]] format through [[Hotbird]] 8 satellite at 13°E.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eutelsat.com/satellites/13ehb8_popd.html |title=Eutelsat Hotbird 8 |accessdate=2008-07-07 }}</ref> The service is encrypted with [[Irdeto Access|Irdeto]] [[conditional access]] system. Until recently the subscribers had the option of buying a specific set-top box, or using any DVB-S Irdeto enabled set-top box, but since September 2009 new subscribers are only allowed to use the company's own set-top box. This change of policy has raised some significant controversy.
Nova has also introduced a [[personal video recorder|PVR]] service, accessible only through a (different) specific set-top box. This service requires an extra subscription fee but also provides the subscriber with the option to watch two different channels on two different TV sets in the same household.
Nova channels were also available through the [[IPTV]] service of [[On Telecoms]]. On Telecoms]subscribers could sign up to watch all the channels offered by Nova but had to pay a separate fee for that service.
===Digital satellite receivers=== Nova Satellite Package includes digital satellite receivers manufactured by [[Pace plc|Pace]]. The current models are NovaBox HD 831 and NovaBox HD PVR 865. Older models were Panasat 1110, Panasat 910, as well as the older Panasat 720i, Panasat 700 and Panasat 642, manufactured by Panasat.
== Channel list == NOVA Greece currently has over 50 subscription channels in its line-up, from Greece, Europe and abroad as well as access to over 200 FTA channels. The line-up also includes over 100 radio stations, and most are available FTA.
{{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Action 24]] * [[Al Jazeera|Al Jazeera Arab]] * [[Al Jazeera English]] * [[Alpha TV]] * [[ANT1]] * [[Arirang (TV network)|Arirang World]] * [[BBC World News]] * [[Bloomberg Television|Bloomberg TV Europe]] * [[Boomerang (EMEA)|Boomerang HD]] * [[CCTV NEWS]] * [[CNN International|CNNi]] * [[Deutsche Welle|DW Europe]] * [[Discovery Channel Europe|Discovery Channel]] * [[Discovery HD Showcase]] * [[Disney Channel (Greece)|Disney Channel]] * [[Disney XD (Europe)|Disney XD]] * [[E!]] * [[E Channel (Greece)|Epsilon TV]] * [[ERT HD]] * [[ERT1]] * [[ERT2]] * [[Euronews]] * [[Eurosport 1]] * [[Eurosport 1|Eurosport 1 HD]] * [[Eurosport 2]] * [[Fashion TV]] * [[Fox (Greece)|FOX]] * [[Fox Sports (United States)|FOX Sport HD]] * [[Fox Life Greece|FOXLife]] * [[France 24|French 24]] * [[History (European TV channel)|History Channel]] * [[JeemTV]] * [[Kontra Channel]] * [[MAD TV (Greece)|MAD]] * [[MAD Greekz]] * [[Makedonia TV|MAKEDONIA TV]] * [[Mega Channel|MEGA]] * [[Mezzo TV|Mezzo]] * [[MTV Europe]] * [[MTV Hits (UK & Ireland)|MTV Hits]] * [[MTV Live HD]] * [[Nat Geo Wild (Europe)|Nat Geo Wild HD]] * [[National Geographic Channel (Greece)|National Geographic Channel]] * [[National Geographic Channel (Greece)|National Geographic Channel HD]] * [[NHK World]] * [[Nickelodeon (Greece)|Nickelodeon]] * [[Nova Life|Nova Life HD]] * [[Nova Cinema (Greece)|Novacinema 1 HD]] * [[Nova Cinema (Greece)|Novacinema 2 HD]] * [[Nova Cinema (Greece)|Novacinema 3 HD]] * [[Nova Cinema (Greece)|Novacinema 4 HD]] * [[Nova Sports|Novasports 1 HD]] * [[Nova Sports|Novasports 2 HD]] * [[Nova Sports|Novasports 3 HD]] * [[Nova Sports|Novasports 4 HD]] * [[Nova Sports|Novasports 5 HD]] * [[Nova Sports|Novasports 24 HD]] * RT Documentaries, also available in HD (RT DOC HD) * [[RT (TV network)|Russia Today]], also available in HD (RT HD) * [[Skai TV]] * [[Star Channel (Greece)|STAR]] * [[Travel Channel (International)|Travel Channel]] * [[TV5Monde|TV5Monde Europe]] * [[VH1 Europe|VH-1]] * [[Vouli Tileorasi]] {{div col end}}
== Criticism == It is said by most television enthusiasts in Greece that the sum of Nova's characteristics show that total customer satisfaction is not by any means comparable to that of subscribers of other European satellite providers, like [[SKY Italia]], [[Sky Digital (UK & Ireland)|Sky UK]] or [[Sky Deutschland]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}
Degradation to the picture quality due to extensive use of heavy [[MPEG]] compression (a technique that offers more available programs at the price of lower total image quality per channel added) also affects terrestrial [[repeaters]] and that practice seriously degrades picture of all commercial national television stations nationwide, since they are fed by Nova.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.nova.gr Official NOVA Greece website] — {{gr icon}} {{en icon}} * [http://www.lyngsat.com/packages/nova.html Lyngsat.com: Nova channel packages and transponder list]

page.title: Party of the Poor (Republic of the Congo)

revision.text:
:''Not to be confused with [[Party of the Poor (Mexico)]]''
The '''Party of the Poor''' ({{lang-fr|Parti des pauvres}})<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sangonet.com/Fich3ActuaInterAfric/ElectionCandPresiCongoB.html|title=Election présidentielle congolaise (République du Congo) 2002: Les Candidats pour le scrutin du 10 mars 2002 - deuxième tour prévu le 7 avril.|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2002|language=French|website= www.sangonet.com/|publisher=|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref> was a [[Populism|populist]] political party in the [[Republic of Congo]].
==History== The Party of the Poor was founded in 1991, by the nun and politician [[Angèle Bandou]], formerly a member of the ''Rassemblement pour la Défense des Pauvres et des Chomeurs au Congo''. As the first ever woman to do so in Congo-Brazzaville, she ran for president in the [[Republic of the Congo presidential election, 1992|1992 presidential election]], receiving less than 1% of the popular vote.<ref name="Dictionary">{{cite book |last=Clark|first=John Frank|date=2012|title=Historical Dictionary of Republic of the Congo|url= |location=[[Lanham, Maryland|Lanham]]|publisher=Scarecrow Press|page=57|isbn=081-084-919-4}}</ref>
Bandou and the Party of the Poor ran again for president, in the [[Republic of the Congo presidential election, 2002|2002 presidential election]]. She received 27,849 votes and came in third place.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=La Cour suprême du Congo proclame les résultats définitifs du scrutin présidentiel |url=http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=713&oldaction=liste&regpay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=0&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=60&select_month=0&select_year=0|deadurl=yes|language=French|newspaper=Les Dépêches de Brazzaville|location=[[Brazzaville]]|date= 29 March 2002|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226070154/http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=713&oldaction=liste&regpay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=0&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=60&select_month=0&select_year=0|archivedate=2012-02-26|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref>
On 26 August 2004, Angèle Bandou was assassinated by unknown assailants in her home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.gabonews.com/women/items/african-women-that-had-a-shot-at-presidency.html|title=African women that had a shot at presidency|last=Fanga|first=Khephren|date=26 February 2013|website=www.en.gabonews.com/|publisher=Gabonews|accessdate=21 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141021210950/http://en.gabonews.com/women/items/african-women-that-had-a-shot-at-presidency.html|archivedate=21 October 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.congopage.com/Angelle-Bandou-une-ancienne|title=Angelle Bandou, une ancienne candidate à l’élection présidentielle assassinée à Brazzaville|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date=27 August 2004|language=French|website=www.congopage.com|publisher=Congopage|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref> According to some sources, the murder was carried out on orders of President [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]].<ref name="Dictionary"/>
==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Party Of The Poor}} [[Category:Defunct political parties in the Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1991]] [[Category:1990s establishments in the Republic of the Congo]] {{RCongo-party-stub}}

'''Powell Alexander Janulus''' (born 1939) is a Canadian [[Polyglotism|polyglot]] who lives in [[White Rock, British Columbia]], and entered the [[Guinness World Records]] in 1985 for fluency in 42 languages.<ref name="Guinness">Boehm, David A.; and Maris Cakars, Cyd Smith, Jim Benagh (1984). ''Guinness Book of World Records 1985.'' Sterling Publishing Co. {{ISBN|978-0806902647}}</ref> To qualify, he had to pass a two-hour conversational fluency test with a native speaker of each of the 42 different languages he spoke at that time.
==Early life==
Powell Janulus was born in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]]. He was exposed to many [[Slavic languages|Slavic]] languages as a child. His [[Poles|Polish]] mother spoke six languages while his [[Lithuanians|Lithuanian]] father spoke at least four. He could speak 13 languages fluently at the age of 18. He attended [[Asian studies|Asian Studies]] at the [[University of British Columbia]] where he attempted to learn [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]]. In an interview he states that he struggled with the academic teaching style.<ref name="Nikulicheva">Nikulicheva, D.B. (2009). ''How to Find your Way to Foreign Languages.'' Flinta. {{ISBN|978-5976508279}}</ref> He became curious about the process of language learning and in the way that children learn languages so easily.<ref name="Dilts">Dilts, Robert (1998). ''Modeling with NLP.'' Meta Publications. Capitola, CA. {{ISBN|978-0916990466}}</ref> He attempted to learn [[Standard Chinese|Chinese]] by having conversations and talking with as many Mandarin speakers as possible.<ref name="Atkinson">Atkinson, Marilyn; and Paul Gossen (2015). ''Velocity Instant Fluency.'' Velocity Learning. {{ISBN|978-0978375515}}</ref>
During his early 20s, he began to develop his methodology for fast language acquisition. In his thirties, he became a court translator and got paid for each language he could translate. He worked to learn two or three languages per year, as each language allowed him to earn more at his job. He was authorized by the [[Provincial Court of British Columbia]], as a court translator in 28 languages. He states that he later became interested in language variations and could quickly learn related languages such as [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. In his 40s, he learned less common languages such as [[Standard Tibetan|Tibetan]], [[Romani language|Romani]], [[Inuit languages|Inuit]] and [[Swahili language|Swahili]]. Later in life, he opened the Geneva Language Institute, a language school in Vancouver.
==World record holder for fluency== In 1985, Powell was entered into the Guinness World Records for spoken [[fluency]] in 42 languages. To qualify, he had to pass a two-hour conversational fluency test with a native speaker of each language he spoke at that time. This testing took place over a one-month period. Powell states that he considers himself skilled in 64 languages and says that he has studied at least 80 languages in total. In an interview, Powell claims that the late [[John Candy]] hired him to help him speak [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] for the movie ''[[Who's Harry Crumb?]]'' He once appeared on [[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson|The Tonight Show]] where talk show host [[Johnny Carson]] invited speakers of 48 different languages to test Janulus.<ref name="Brown">{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Stacy|title=Multilingual Speaker to Give Area Seminar|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/MULTILINGUAL+SPEAKER+TO+GIVE+AREA+SEMINAR.-a083809089|website=Daily News (Los Angeles)|date=January 26, 1998}}</ref>
It was reported that Powell speaks the following 42 languages: [[French language|French]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[German language|German]], [[Dutch language|Dutch]], [[Frisian languages|Frisian]], [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]], [[Danish language|Danish]], [[Swedish language|Swedish]], [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]], [[Polish language|Polish]], [[Czech language|Czech]], [[Serbian language|Serbian]], [[Slovak language|Slovak]], [[Slovene language|Slovene]], [[Kashubian language|Kashubian]], [[Lusatian language|Lusatian]], [[Sorbian languages|Wendish]], [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]], [[Macedonian language|Macedonian]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Hindi languages|Hindi]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], [[Urdu]], [[Armenian language|Armenian]], [[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]], [[Standard Tibetan|Tibetan]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]], [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]], [[Cantonese language|Cantonese]], [[Croatian language|Croatian]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Kurdish languages|Kurdish]], [[Finnish language|Finnish]], [[Korean language|Korean]] and [[Persian language|Persian]]. This list does not include [[English language|English]], which is his [[First language|native language]], or the many other languages in which he has some proficiency.<ref name="Brown"/>
==Recent years==
Powell was reported to have died in 2006, however this was inaccurate. In an interview he stated that his disappearance was due to a stroke he suffered at that time. He reported that he lost his ability to speak English, due to brain damage. He claimed to have regained his English spoken ability by speaking Dutch with a nurse. He is currently retired and living in [[White Rock, British Columbia]].<ref name="Atkinson"/> In August 2013, he was again the subject of a language testing event during which he spoke at least 20 languages and modeled the learning process with [[Korean language|Korean]] and [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]].

in the diocese --> <!---- Information ----> | denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] | rite = [[Roman Rite]] | established = 28 June 1971 ({{age|1971|6|28}} years ago) | cathedral = Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception of Mary in [[Jeju Province]] | cocathedral = | patron = | priests = <!-- Number of priests in the diocese --> <!---- Current leadership ----> | pope = {{Incumbent pope}} | bishop = [[Peter Woo-il Kang]] | bishop_title = Bishop | metro_archbishop = Hyginus Kim Hee Jong | coadjutor = | auxiliary_bishops = | vicar_general = | emeritus_bishops = [[Paul Chang-ryul Kim]] <!---- Map ----> | map = Diocese of Jeju.svg | map_alt = | map_caption = <!---- Website ----> | website = {{url|http://www.diocesecheju.org/}} | footnotes = }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Cheju''' (제주, also romanized '''Jeju''', {{lang-la|Dioecesis Cheiuensis}}) is a [[Latin rite]] [[suffragan diocese]] in the [[ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Gwangju|Archdiocese of Gwangju]], [[South Korea]], yet depends on the missionary [[Roman Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples]].
Its episcopal see and [[mother church]] is Cheju Joong-Ang Jungang [[Cathedral]] of the [[Immaculate Conception of Mary]], in [[Jeju City]]제주시, in [[Seoul-teukbyeolsi]] 서울특별시.
== History == * It was created on 28 June 1971 by [[Pope Paul VI]] as '''[[Apostolic Prefecture]] of Jeju''' 제주 / Cheju / 濟州 (正體中文) / Cheiuen(sis) (Latin), exempt, on territory split off from its (then future) Metropolitan, the [[Archdiocese of Gwangju]] 광주) * The [[episcopal see]] was elevated on 21 March 1977, also by [[Pope Paul VI]] to '''Diocese of Jeju''' 제주 / Cheju / 濟州 (正體中文) / Cheiuen(sis) (Latin).<ref name=GCatholic>{{cite web|url=http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/chej0.htm|title=Diocese of Jeju|publisher=Giga Catholic|accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref>
== Statistics == As per 2014, it pastorally served 71,845 Catholics (11.9% of 604,670 total) on 1,849 km² in 27 parishes with 51 priests (44 diocesan, 7 religious), 1 deacon, 110 lay religious (7 brothers, 103 sisters) and 17 seminarians.
== Ordinaries == (all [[Roman Rite]])
;''Apostolic Prefecture of Jeju 제주 **''[[Apostolic Administrator]] [[Harold Hyun]] = Harold William Henry (현 하롤드), [[Columban Missionaries]] (S.S.C.M.E.) (born USA) (1971.06.28 – death 1976.03.01), [[Titular Archbishop]] of [[Thubunæ in Numidia]] (1971.06.28 – 1976.03.01); previously [[Apostolic Administrator sede plena]] of [[Apostolic Vicariate of Gwangju]] 광주 (South Korea) (1950.07 – 1957.01.26), [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Corydala]] (1957.01.26 – 1962.03.10) as last [[Apostolic Vicar]] of Gwangju 광주 (1957.01.26 – 1962.03.10), (see) promoted first as Metropolitan Archbishop of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Gwangju|Archdiocese of Gwangju]] 광주 (South Korea) (1962.03.10 – retired 1971.06.28)
;''Suffragan Bishops of Jeju 제주 * [[Michael Jung-il Park]] = Michael Pak Jeong-il (1977.04.15 – 1982.06.08), next Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Jeonju|Jeonju]] 전주 (South Korea) (1982.06.08 – 1988.12.15), Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Masan|Masan]] 마산 (South Korea) (1988.12.15 – retired 2002.11.11), President of Catholic Bishops’ Conference of Korea (1999 – 2002 * [[Paul Chang-ryul Kim]] = Paul Kim Tchang-ryeol (1983.11.11 – retired 2002.07.20) * [[Peter Woo-il Kang]] = Peter Kang U-il (2002.07.20 – ...), President of Catholic Bishops’ Conference of Korea (2008.10.16 – 2014.10.30); previously [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Balecium]] (1985.12.21 – 2002.07.20) as [[Auxiliary Bishop]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Seoul|Archdiocese of Seoul]] 서울 (South Korea) (1985.12.21 – 2002.07.20), Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Jeju|Jeju]] 제주 (South Korea) (2002.07.20 – ...) ** [[Coadjutor Bishop]] (2017.06.28 – ...): [[Bishop-elect]] Pius Moon Chang-woo (문창우(文昌宇), no titular see

{{more citations needed|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox Political party |country = Angola | name = Social Renewal Party |native_name = Partido de Renovação Social |colorcode = orange |logo = Prs logo.gif |leader = |president = [[Eduardo Kuangana]] |secretary_general = |chairperson = |spokesperson = |leader1_name = |slogan = Peace, Democracy, Progress |foundation = November 18, 1990 |dissolution = |headquarters = Rua nº1, Martires de Kifangondo n. 33 D, [[Luanda]], [[Angola]] |newspaper = |youth_wing = Social Renewal Youth |wing1_title = [[Women's wing]] |wing1 = Social Renewal Women's Union |membership_year = |membership = |ideology = [[Federalism]]
[[Progressivism]][http://www.dw.de/terceiro-maior-partido-angolano-prs-quer-alargar-influ%C3%AAncia-nas-elei%C3%A7%C3%B5es-gerais/a-16134758 Terceiro maior partido angolano, PRS quer alargar influência nas eleições gerais] - Deutsche Welle |national = |international = |colors = |position = [[Centre-left politics|Centre-left]][http://www.portalangop.co.ao/angola/pt_pt/noticias/politica/2012/7/32/PRS-defende-participacao-activa-dos-cidadaos-governacao-pais,102541e6-f94c-45e4-9485-6a401cba9e95.html PRS defende participação activa dos cidadãos na governação do país] - Agência Angola Press |seats1_title = Seats in the [[National Assembly of Angola|National Assembly]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|2|220|hex=orange}} |website = [http://www.prs-angola.com Website of the PRS] |flag = [[Image:Prsangola.png|200px|PRS banner]] |footnotes = }} The '''Social Renewal Party''' (''Partido de Renovação Social'') is a [[political party]] in [[Angola]]. The party was founded in 1991. It is mainly based within the [[Chokwe people|Chokwe]] ethnic group. In the 1992 elections it won six seats. In 1999 the party passed through a period of inner strife, in which four MPs were expelled from the party. The PRS won 3.17% of the vote in the [[Angolan parliamentary election, 2008|September 2008 parliamentary election]], winning eight seats out of 220 seats.[http://www.cne.ao/ National Electoral Commission website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080419071220/http://www.cne.ao/ |date=2008-04-19 }} {{pt icon}}. It performed particularly well in [[Lunda Sul]] and [[Lunda Norte]] provinces, although it still placed second behind the governing [[Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola]] (MPLA) in those provinces.[http://www.cne.ao/graficos_provinciais/mapa_lsul.html Results for Lunda Sul] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913055856/http://www.cne.ao/graficos_provinciais/mapa_lsul.html |date=2008-09-13 }}, CNE website {{pt icon}}.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080909123308/http://www.cne.ao/graficos_provinciais/mapa_lnorte.html Results for Lunda Norte], CNE website {{pt icon}}. The youth wing of the party is Social Renewal Youth (JURS).{{cite book|author=Augusto Santana|title=Political parties and political evolution in Angola|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M2YWAQAAIAAJ|date=1 January 2006|publisher=EISA|isbn=978-1-920095-53-6|page=45}} ==References== {{reflist}} *[http://www.unhcr.org/home/RSDCOI/3ae6a6710.pdf] ==External links== *[http://www.prs-angola.com/ Official '''PRS−Social Renewal Party''' website]—{{pt icon}} {{Angolan political parties}} [[Category:Political parties in Angola]] [[Category:Liberal parties in Angola]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1991]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Angola]] {{Angola-party-stub}}

/* Coach Transport in Europe */[[WP:GenFixes]] on, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: y’s → y's
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=March 2017}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{multiple image|perrow = 2|total_width=400 | image1 =International E Road Network green.png |width1=840|height1=600 | caption1 = [[International E-road network|E-Road Network]] over 1990 borders | image2 = High Speed Railroad Map of Europe.svg |width2=800|height2=600 | caption2 = Operational high-speed railway lines | image3= Europe busiest airports.png | caption3 = Busiest airports as of 2007 |width3=1475|height3=1200 | image4 = European Rivers.gif | caption4 = Navigable rivers and canals|width4=3000|height4=2000 | header = Transport networks in Europe }}
'''Transport in Europe''' provides for the movement needs of over 700 million people<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esa.un.org/unpp/index.asp |title=World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision |date=11 March 2009 |publisher=''[[United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs]]'' |accessdate=18 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012190153/http://esa.un.org/unpp/index.asp |archivedate=12 October 2009 }}</ref> and associated freight. The political geography of Europe divides the continent into over 50 sovereign states and territories. This fragmentation, along with increased movement of people since the [[industrial revolution]], has led to a high level of cooperation between European countries in developing and maintaining transport networks. [[Supranational]] and intergovernmental organisations such as the [[European Union]] (EU), [[Council of Europe]] and the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]] have led to the development of international standards and agreements that allow people and freight to cross the borders of Europe, largely with unique levels of freedom and ease.
Road, rail, air and water transportation are all prevalent and important across Europe. Europe was the location of the world's first railways and motorways and is now the location of some of the world's busiest ports and airports. The [[Schengen Area]] enables border control-free travel between 26 European countries. Freight transportation has a high level of [[Intermodal freight transport|intermodal]] compatibility and the [[European Economic Area]] allows the free movement of goods across 30 states.
A review of critical success factors for the delivery of transport infrastructure projects in Europe is presented in.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Locatelli|first=Giorgio|last2=Invernizzi|first2=Diletta Colette|last3=Brookes|first3=Naomi J.|date=2017-04-01|title=Project characteristics and performance in Europe: An empirical analysis for large transport infrastructure projects|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0965856416300817|journal=Transportation Research Part A: Policy and Practice|volume=98|pages=108–122|doi=10.1016/j.tra.2017.01.024}}</ref>
==Rail transport== [[File:Bruxelles-Midi 0005.jpg|thumb|right|221x221px|A German [[ICE 3]], a French [[Thalys]] and a French-British [[Eurostar]] at [[Brussels South railway station]].]] {{Main|Rail transport in Europe}}
Powered rail transport began in England in the early 19th century with the invention of the [[steam engine]]. The modern European rail network spans the entire continent and provides passenger and freight movement. There are significant [[high-speed rail]] passenger networks such as the [[TGV]] in [[France]] and the [[High-speed rail in Spain|LAV]] in Spain. The [[Channel Tunnel]] connects the [[United Kingdom]] with [[France]], [[Belgium]] and thus the whole of the European rail system, and was called one of the seven wonders of the modern world by the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]].<ref>[http://www.asce.org/history/seven_wonders.cfm Seven wonders of the modern world]</ref>
Various method of [[rail electrification]] are used, as well as much unelectrified track. [[Standard gauge]] is widespread in Central and Western Europe, while [[Russian gauge]] predominates in parts of Eastern Europe – mainline services on the [[Iberian peninsula]] and the island of [[Ireland (island)|Ireland]] use the rarer [[Iberian gauge]] and [[Irish gauge]] respectively. The [[European Rail Traffic Management System]] is an EU initiative to create a Europe-wide standard for train signalling.
Rail infrastructure, freight transport and passenger services are provided by a combination of local and national governments and private companies. Passenger ticketing varies from country to country and service to service. The [[Eurail Pass]] is a rail pass for 18 European countries; it is only available for persons who do not live in Europe, [[Morocco]], Algeria and [[Tunisia]]. [[Inter Rail]] passes allow multi-journey travel around Europe for people living in Europe and surrounding countries.
=== Rapid Transit === [[File:London Underground full map.svg|thumb|189x189px|A geographic map of London's rapid transit service, known as the [[London Underground]].]] Many [[Lists of cities in Europe|cities]] across Europe have a [[Rapid transit|rapid transit system]], commonly referred to as a metro, which is an electric railway. The world's first underground railway, the Metropolitan Railway, was opened in London in 1863. It is now part of London's rapid transit system referred to as the [[London Underground]], which is part of the [[Transport in London|city's public transportation system]] managed by [[Transport for London|TfL]]. Other European cities with a rapid transit system include: [[Paris Métro|Paris]], [[Prague Metro|Prague]] and [[Copenhagen Metro|Copenhagen]].
==Coach Transport in Europe==
In the last few years, many countries in Europe have decided to liberalise the market for medium/long distance coach transportation. This move has already proven to be helping both the economies and the Europeans.
The bus is the cheapest method of transportation but this doesn’t mean that the trip is unbearable. Many companies are making adjustments so that their fleets can be as comfortable as trains. Toilettes and power have been added to the coaches and always more are being equipped with WiFi.
In order to make it even easier and even cheaper, platforms for comparison have been created. And now some, like [[SoBus]], have integrated the booking process without redirection to the company's website.
==Air transport== [[File:BCN-T1.jpg|thumb|250px|Aircraft from [[LOT Polish Airlines]], [[Brussels Airlines]], [[airBaltic]] and [[Air Europa]] at [[Barcelona Airport]].]] Despite an extensive road and rail network, 43% of international travel within the EU was by air in 2013.<ref name="intra-EU flows">{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Tourism_statistics_-_intra-EU_tourism_flows|title=Tourism statistics - intra-EU tourism flows |publisher=Eurostat|date=June 2015|accessdate=18 March 2016}}</ref> [[Air travel]] is particularly important for peripheral nations such as [[Spain]] and [[Greece]] and island nations such as [[Malta]] and [[Cyprus]], where a large majority of border crossings are by air.<ref name="intra-EU flows"/> A large tourism industry also attracts many visitors to Europe, most of whom arrive into one of Europe's many large international airports – [[List of the busiest airports in Europe|major hubs]] include [[London Heathrow]], [[Istanbul Atatürk Airport|Istanbul Atatürk]], [[Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport|Paris-Charles De Gaulle]], [[Frankfurt Airport|Frankfurt]] and [[Amsterdam Airport Schiphol|Amsterdam Schiphol]]. The advent of [[low cost carriers]] in recent years{{when|date=November 2017}} has led to a large increase in air travel within Europe. Air transportation is now often the cheapest way of travelling between cities. This increase in air travel has led to problems of airspace overcrowding and environmental concerns. The [[Single European Sky]] is one initiative aimed at solving these problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurocontrol.int/ses/public/standard_page/sk_ses.html|title=The Single European Sky|date=13 January 2009|publisher=''[[European Organisation for the Safety of Air Navigation]]''|accessdate=18 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120729121951/www.eurocontrol.int/ses/public/standard_page/sk_ses.html|archivedate=29 July 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Within the European Union, the complete [[freedoms of the air]] and the world's most extensive [[cabotage]] agreements allow [[budget airline]]s to operate freely across the EU.<ref name="havel">{{cite book|last1=Havel|first1=Brian F.|title=The Principles and Practice of International Aviation Law|date=31 March 2014|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107020528|pages=50–53|url=https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=C8H2AgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA51&ots=ShuKdGSAP2&dq=chile%20cabotage&pg=PA50#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref> Cheap air travel is spurred on by the trend for regional airports levying low fees to market themselves as serving large cities quite far away. [[Ryanair]] is especially noted for this, since it primarily flies out of regional airports up to 150 kilometres away from the cities they are said to serve. A primary example of this is the [[Weeze]]-[[Skavsta]] flight, where Weeze mainly serves the [[Nijmegen]]/[[Kleve]] area, while Skavsta serves [[Nyköping]]/[[Oxelösund]]. Ryanair however, markets this flight as [[Düsseldorf]]-[[Stockholm]], which are both 80–90 kilometres away from these airports, resulting in up to four hours of ground transportation just to get to and from the airport.
== Sea and river transport == [[File:Schiffsstau auf dem Rhein bei Köln 2013-08-20-05.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Ships on the [[Rhine]] at [[Cologne]].]] The [[Port of Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]] is the largest port in Europe and one of the busiest ports in the world, handling some 440 million metric tons of cargo in 2013.<ref name="RPA Stat13">{{cite press release |date=1 June 2014 |title=Port Statistics 2013 |url=http://www.portofrotterdam.com/en/Port/port-statistics/Documents/Port-statistics-2013.pdf |page=8 |publisher=Rotterdam Port Authority |accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref> When the associated [[Europoort]] industrial area is included, Rotterdam is by certain measurements the [[world's busiest port]]. Two thirds of all inland water freight shipping within the [[European Union|E.U.]], and 40% of containers, pass through the Netherlands.<ref name="NFIA Seaports">{{cite web |url=http://www.nfia.com/seaports.html |title=Seaports - Netherlands Foreign Investment Agency |date=c. 2010 |website=www.nfia.com |publisher=Netherlands Foreign Investment Agency |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> Other large ports are the [[Port of Hamburg]] in [[Germany]] and the [[Port of Antwerp]] in [[Belgium]]. They are all a part of the so-called "Northern Range".
The [[English Channel]] is one of the world's busiest seaways carrying over 400 ships per day<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.mcga.gov.uk/c4mca/mcga07-home/emergencyresponse/mcga-searchandrescue/mcga-hmcgsar-sarsystem/channel_navigation_information_service__cnis_/the_dover_strait.htm| title=The Dover Strait| publisher=[[Maritime and Coastguard Agency]]| year=2007| accessdate=8 October 2008| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831173118/http://www.mcga.gov.uk/c4mca/mcga07-home/emergencyresponse/mcga-searchandrescue/mcga-hmcgsar-sarsystem/channel_navigation_information_service__cnis_/the_dover_strait.htm| archivedate=31 August 2010| df=dmy-all}}</ref> between Europe's [[North Sea]] and [[Baltic Sea]] ports and the rest of the world.
As well as its role in freight movement, sea transport is an important part of Europe's energy supply. Europe is one of the world's major [[oil tanker]] discharge destinations. Energy is also supplied to Europe by sea in the form of [[LNG]]. The [[South Hook LNG terminal]] at [[Milford Haven]], Wales is Europe's largest LNG terminal.<ref name=bbc200309>{{cite news| publisher= [[BBC News]]| url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_west/7952415.stm| title= Port awaits liquid gas delivery| date=20 March 2009| accessdate=20 March 2009}}</ref>

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-213 | image = Navstar-2F.jpg | image_caption = A Block IIF GPS satellite | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 2011-036A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=2011-036A|title=Navstar 66|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=3 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 37753 | mission_duration = 12 years (planned) | spacecraft = GPS SVN-63 (IIF-2) | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block IIF]] | manufacturer = [[Boeing]] | launch_mass = {{convert|1630|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|16 July 2011, 06:41|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta IV|Delta IV-M+(4,2)]],}} D355 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 37|SLC-37B]] | launch_contractor = [[United Launch Alliance|ULA]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20463|km|sp=us}} | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|20452|km|sp=us}} | orbit_inclination = 55 degrees | orbit_period = 729.16 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-232''', also known as '''GPS IIF-2''', and '''GPS SVN-63''', is an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which forms part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the second of twelve [[GPS Block IIF|Block IIF]] satellites to be launched. Built by [[Boeing]] and launched by [[United Launch Alliance]], USA-232 was launched at 06:41 UTC on 16 July 2011, atop a [[Delta IV]] carrier rocket, flight number D355, flying in the Medium+(4,2) configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=12 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 37|Space Launch Complex 37B]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=12 July 2012}} and placed USA-232 directly into [[medium Earth orbit]]. As of 24 July 2011, USA-232 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|20452|km|sp=us}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20463|km|sp=us}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 729.16 minutes, and 55.0 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=12 July 2012}} It is used to broadcast the PRN 01 signal, and operates in slot 2 of plane D of the GPS constellation. The satellite has a design life of 15 years and a mass of {{convert|1630|kg}}. {{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2f.htm|title=GPS-2F (Navstar-2F)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=12 July 2012}} As of 2012 it remains in service. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 2011}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2011]] [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by Delta IV rockets]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

[[File:SZP_1.png|thumb|400px]]
{{Orphan|date=April 2011}}
'''United States of Poland''' ({{Lang-pl|Stany Zjednoczone Polski}}) was an unrealized political concept of reborn [[Poland]], created by [[Ignacy Jan Paderewski]] (1860–1941). It was first presented in Paderewski Memorial, given to US President [[Woodrow Wilson]] on 11 January 1917.
Paderewski's idea postulated rebuilding a Polish state as [[federation]], in which [[constitution]] and law would guarantee equality to citizens, ethnic and religious groups. Territory would engulf most of pre-[[Partitions of Poland|partitioned]] territory. Taking into account of that time population, the country would have 54 million citizens. On its head would be a President with a title of the [[King]] of [[Poland]], [[Lithuania]], [[Polesia]] and [[Halych]].<ref name= "zw">Joanna Gierowska-Kałłaur ''Zarząd Cywilny Ziem Wschodnich (19 lutego 1919 – 9 września 1920)'', Neriton, Instytut Historii PAN, Warszawa 2003, p.19, {{ISBN|83-88973-60-6}}</ref>
==Administrative regions== United States of Poland were to be a number of [[Autonomous area|autonomous states]] including: *Kingdom of Poland *Kingdom of Lithuania *Kingdom of Polesia *Kingdom of Galitia-Podole *Kingdom of Volhynia
Later the concept of Galitia-Podole was supplanted by Kingdom of [[Halych]], in separate memorial there was also postulate of incorporating a [[Eastern Prussia]] into it.<ref name="zw" />
===Ukrainian problem===
The postulate of creation of Kingdoms of Halych and Polesia on lands which were inhabited by large numbers of [[Ukrainians]] did not satisfy their appetites for creation of independent state. Paderewski did not pursue the matter due to large percentage of Ukrainian population living in those regions with a different politics and demography.
